May I suggest you dry out glass before you add metallic sodium? We do flame out adsorbed water to the glass, under vacuum. Borosilicate glass do bind water coordinativelly, forming an acid catalyst. Don't be surprised that you are forming sodium-borosilicate, a solid acid chemical. Besides as you dissolve Na in Hg, you increase the surface area exposing it to O2 (atmospheric oxygen) a dirradical gas. That's why we use to carry these "research" under dry gases, i.e. Argon, not in air. By the way metallic Gallium also sticks to the borosilicate glass under air. Inorganic chemistry is not a trivial subject. "God created the solids, the evil produced the surfaces".

That's not what VPNs are for, and practically every website on the Internet already uses encryption for all it's communication with your web browser. If the little padlock symbol to the left of the web page's address is locked tight, then your connection is encrypted using TLS, the global standard for web privacy. It's all built-in to browsers and websites, no need to install anything, you already have encryption. At best, your ISP could tell what sites you've connected to, but not the page you're looking at, nor any information you send them, filling in forms etc. All they get is the address of the server itself, pretty useless.

VPNs are meant for office workers, who want to connect to their company's network. Instead of connecting directly to the company network with a cable, they use the Internet instead. It's not a private, off-Internet network, it's a virtual private network. You use the Internet as the equivalent on a network cable, between you and your office, and it's encrypted for the sake of privacy.

If you don't have an office network to connect to, you don't need a VPN. If you do, you likely already have one. The VPN advertised here essentially connects you to the Internet, through the Internet! You have an encrypted connection between your computer and, say, Switzerland. Then in Switzerland there's an Internet connection that you connect to. So you appear to be browsing from Switzerland. That's really limited usefulness. All the other stuff, virus protection, encryption, you get from somewhere else.

Most people don't need a VPN, and those who do, already have one.

Yes I suppose you could connect to Netflix in Australia. Though you're still using the same login and password Netflix gave you, so they know who you are and where you're located cos you have a customer account. At the moment they might allow you to watch foreign stuff on foreign servers. They could switch that off at any time, similarly they could allow users to view foreign content at any time, if they wanted to. It's a pretty weak reason to do this.

There's also the issue of having to trust the VPN company itself. They become your Internet connection. Everything you access, is through them. Sure they make promises about privacy, of course they do. But if you can trust them, why can't you trust your own ISP? Unless you live in North Korea or something. But I doubt North Korea allows people to connect to VPNs.

It's annoying how these ads all contain, if not lies, then "technically true" information. It's as close to lying without actually lying, some VPN companies have already copped trouble for misleading advertising.

"Pure nitrogen is denser than air." Not the way I learned it. Gases at the same temperature and pressure have density directly proportional to molecular weight -- and air, at ~20% oxygen, has an effective molecular weight of around 29 (Wikipedia gives it as 28.97), while pure nitrogen has molecular weight of 28. Not a useful lifting gas for a balloon, but clearly not denser than air.

Want a denser-than-air inert gas, try argon. If you're not worried about flammability, butane would work well (no oxygen, so the sodium in this experiment wouldn't react with the butane -- and much cheaper than argon).

Good grief. It's hard to know what to think. This could have been educational and interesting if this guy knew any of the chemistry involved but, sadly, he's operating at just about the level of Grant Thompson on his original King of Random, the Internet's most egregious waste of time and material.


"So this time I decided to mix some carbon tetrachloride with borax and hydrofluoric acid in a 1 liter Erlenmeyer flask sitting on my hibachi at 500° in the back yard. I guess I'd forgotten the effect of hydrofluoric acid on glass, but we're OK, thanks to voice recognition technology. I can dictate the script for this show even without my eyes and 7 of my fingers. This really brings home the importance of wearing eye protection for those of you who might try this at home."


The point where he started to generate mercury vapor and smoke of uncertain composition reminded me of a patient I had 35 years ago (yeah, I'm a doctor, and I have a sphincter scrunching story for every occasion). I live smack in the middle of the Sierra Nevada foothills in California, the epicenter of the Gold Rush of 1849. Even now, 170 years later the small streams in every direction are clogged with inveterate optimists who plan to retire on the profit from the 6 lb. gold nugget they expect to pan out of Squirrel Creek. It's ruined the trout fishing — you can't cast in any direction without snagging one of these lunkheads.


I digress. My patient had been panning up in the hills and was extracting the tiny bit of gold in the quartz dust he held IN A TEASPOON. He poured a little Mercury into the spoon, and proceeded to heat the mixture over a small flame. After an hour or so sitting over this process, inhaling the fumes, he realized he couldn't stand, couldn't walk or use his hands, and could barely talk.


As I type this, I notice a thumbnail to the right for a video by the latest genius to hold the crown of The King of Random. He's mixing super glue and cinnamon. Yes — super glue and cinnamon. Why? I guess it's what he found in his cupboard. I can hardly wait to skip it.

Food but not Na, can be blanketed with CO2 with MG 44.

@ 12:50 comment "Nitrogen is denser than air" - I don't think this is correct. Air is a mix of about 79% N2, 20% O2 and a fractional % of other gases. N2 has atomic number 7, O2 is atomic number 8 which tends to suggest O2 is heavier than air and N2. Looking at densities at STP (Std temp & press) O2 is heavier than air (according to the density table I looked at) both air and N2. I think the reason this works is the flask neck is so small, there is insufficient time for the atmospheric air to enter the flask to mess with the reaction.

I wonder....The crystals would form in a super-saturated condition (because there's no nucleation sites). Once crystalization started, it would take off like a rocket, as such solutions do. Could that crystalization have captured liquid mercury within the crystals? We know this can happen--they're called fluid inclusions, and can have multiple phases. (I once nearly got tossed out of a jewelry store for pointing out the diamond has a fluid inclusion--which cost them a sale, as to me it increased the value of the stone.) But I haven't seen it for dendritic crystals. Mercury and sodium are weird, though, at least compared to silicates, so maybe this was happening to a certain extent...This would also explain the "paste" on the surface of the liquid material. The different solid Na/Hg phases would have different melting points, but seem to be (at least somewhat) soluble in the liquid material. As it cools, the phases with higher melting points would fall out of solution. This is called fractional crystalization. It has a lot of uses--for example, you can use it to increase alcohol content of fluids, because water ice forms at a higher temperature than water/alcohol mixture ices do. (No, I'm not recommending it--I'm just saying, I've seen it done.) The thing to remember about liquids is that they're liquid ON AVERAGE. At the atomic scale you get very small, very short-lived crystals forming constantly; they just get dissolved as soon as they from. Random chance can, if the liquid is cooled far enough below the freezing point, produce larger crystals that last longer. This works during any phase change--it's why you don't microwave water without something like chop sticks in it. But with 6 solid phases, this Na/Hg stuff presents a rather unique opportunity to observe this sort of reaction.

FYI, you don't actually need to start with any sodium metal to make sodium amalgam. You just need to electrolyze salt water with a mercury cathode and a heavy current and voila, you have your sodium amalgam. You can't NORMALLY make much progress making sodium metal by electrolysis of salt water since it would react with the water as you form it, but when the cathode is mercury it's an exception, because when it is an alloy that is mostly mercury, it reacts much slower with the water, and what will happen is that the concentration of sodium in the alloy will increase until it reaches an equilibrium rate where it is formed and dissolved into the mercury at the same rate that the sodium atoms that make it to the surface react with the water. This is also a viable way of making sodium metal at room temperature, rather than trying to melt salt and pass electricity through it and not have the hot molten sodium burst into flames when it floats to the surface. The only problem is that if you want to have pure sodium at the end, you would then have to distill it away from the mercury, and with that amount of nuisance, you might as well just electrolyze molten salt in a box filled with argon to begin with. Also, without the distillation, the best you'll probably be able to do is maybe 5% sodium 95% mercury, in other words a concentration where it reacts with the water slowly and resembles alkaseltzer. That's 5% by volume. When you talk about percentage in the video you're obviously talking about by weight. And what with the huge difference in density between mercury and sodium that makes a big difference.

Actually it's way easier than you think to make sodium amalgam. You don't need to even have any pure sodium metal to mix with mercury. All you need is to do electrolysis of salt water with a mercury cathode. The more current you put through it, the higher the percentage of sodium you can attain, since obviously it will react with the water, but it will start as pure mercury and gain in percentage as sodium until it reaches equilibrium. You should be able to reduce sodium into the metal at a rate so that it only reacts with water at the level of alkaseltzer, for about 5% sodium total (by number of atoms.... so that'd be less than 1% by weight, if you want to measure it that way). This will still be liquid at room temperature, but you can make it more pure sodium by one stage of distillation. This is actually a decent method of making sodium metal using nothing but relatively low temperatures.


Also, NO, pure nitrogen is NOT denser than air, it is LESS dense than air. This should be obvious. Air is a mixture of nitrogen with other gases that are all denser than nitrogen. Namely oxygen (denser than nitrogen), argon (denser than nitrogen) and carbon dioxide (denser than nitrogen). What on EARTH would ever give you the idea that pure nitrogen was denser than air?

A couple of points - as mentioned by other commenters, nitrogen is slightly lighter than air, not heavier. But it's OK for creating an inert covering for your amalgam if you're quick enough at stoppering the container.

Mineral oil is not, of course, a solvent for sodium metal (if it were, your sodium would be in solution, wouldn't it!)

It should have come as no surprise to you that the article by Read and Lucarini on the large-scale preparation of sodium amalgam in the lab was an old paper - it says so at the bottom of the page! (Industrial & Engineering Chemistry, 1925, vol. 17, part 5, p. 480 [a one-page-only article] for those of you voyeurs who understand that there's more to chemistry than the miserly offerings we find on the internet).

Interesting and great news that you've found a kind landlord who's provided you with some premises to work in - they know about the nature of your experiments I take it?

You're not sure what use to make of your sodium amalgam? Ooooooh! Do you not have access to any alpha, beta-unsaturated carbonyl compounds (or similar)? Your amalgam should work a treat at reducing them. Also, try a reaction with an alcohol to make the corresponding sodium alcoholate as a strong base.

You may like to try making an amalgam with about 35-45% Na by weight; this should also be a liquid at round about room temperature or a little above. The (approx. 40%) eutectic melts at about 21 C.

Good luck, best wishes, and please do keep up the good work :)

Cool video! I'd like to see more lithium work.  It's such as important component of reagents but working with it is difficult.  Also, the lithium in batteries is pretty dirty. I've been doing some experiments and found that phosphoric acid is a great way to separate it from the impurity in the batteries. I had been wondering if there isn't a mercury route that would be useful.  You certainly have to be careful making the hydroxide or the phosphate.  Even with a flow of argon into the container I found ignitions to be a problem. Once of the big things is the use of glass.  Once hot lithium bubbling around on the surface of liquid comes in contact with the glass container, it reduces it and will burn a hole right through it.  I found that a large thing nalgene container was much better in that it tended to survive flame-ups with minimal damage. However, forced submersion is absolutely the only sure fire way to avoid the problems!

Hey NileRed, I know your main objective with this channel is to entretain (while educating a bit). I honestly admire your hard work that is effectively shaping how science is communicating in the 21st century. But as you already experienced, the research step is really hard and I'm pretty sure it takes a lot of your time to find the information you need to put these experiments together. I see you usually reference videos in the description, but not the actual papers you read. Some appear in the video sometimes (like this one), but showing the references in the description would be very useful for other students and industry people that are interested in the details.

Think about it - the work you do here has many orders of magnitude more impact than any scientific paper out there. You literally translate and present in a visually understandable way what chemistry is about. You're highly searchable and visible as a free resource to the public. But you are kinda responsible to reference to these hard working scientists, because they are unfortunate to (mostly) not have the time neither the talent to create videos that communicate with the same level of impact as you do. So think about the low-paid hard-working graduate student in the bottom of the food chain - He would be really grateful if you referenced his paper in a video. As a graduate student myself (in a completely different field, Mech. E.), I assure you that writing a paper most of the time feels like shouting in the void. But I also am understanding that the paper - even though it is a crippled format for today's technology - is how scientists worldwide get their food in their tables. It is their bottomline. So they kinda have to write like that.

I wrote a lot but the main point here is that just putting the link or the reference of the papers and the author's names would be a benefit that should come at a small cost for you (I'm sure you keep track of the relevant papers you found). I'm not even into chemistry and I still do watch your content - and I definitely feel what those graduate students have to do in order to write the papers you see out there. The paper format makes it so bland and cold that it is easy to forget that there are actual people behind it.
